An article in the 25 Jan 1968 LAT stated that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc. (MGM) purchased film rights to Norman Juster’s 1961 children’s novel, The Phantom Tollbooth, in Jan 1966. The project, estimated to cost $2 million, was announced in a 22 Apr 1966 DV item, which stated that Chuck Jones, MGM’s head of animation, would direct. Jones and co-producer Les Goldman were said to be meeting with composers and lyricists at that time.

The film marked MGM’s first feature-length animated picture, according to the 30 Aug 1967 Var. Production began on 3 Apr 1967 with the shooting of live-action sequences in San Francisco, CA, and, later, at MGM studios in Culver City, CA, as noted in the 21 Apr 1967 DV and 25 Jan 1968 LAT. Jones initially estimated that the live-action sequences, which would serve as book-ends to the animated portion, would run a total of fifteen minutes, while the animation would run ninety minutes; however, the final running time of the film was ninety minutes in total.

Jones predicted in the 25 Jan 1968 LAT that he would complete 4,000 drawings before sending them to animators, to work on their own versions. The 9 Feb 1968 DV reported that layouts and designs were finished, and work on an estimated 7,200 feet of animated film was scheduled to begin in mid-Mar 1968. By 2 Oct 1969, post-production had begun, as noted in that day’s DV.

An article in the 25 Jan 1968 LAT stated that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc. (MGM) purchased film rights to Norman Juster’s 1961 children’s novel, The Phantom Tollbooth, in Jan 1966. The project, estimated to cost $2 million, was announced in a 22 Apr 1966 DV item, which stated that Chuck Jones, MGM’s head of animation, would direct. Jones and co-producer Les Goldman were said to be meeting with composers and lyricists at that time.

The film marked MGM’s first feature-length animated picture, according to the 30 Aug 1967 Var. Production began on 3 Apr 1967 with the shooting of live-action sequences in San Francisco, CA, and, later, at MGM studios in Culver City, CA, as noted in the 21 Apr 1967 DV and 25 Jan 1968 LAT. Jones initially estimated that the live-action sequences, which would serve as book-ends to the animated portion, would run a total of fifteen minutes, while the animation would run ninety minutes; however, the final running time of the film was ninety minutes in total.

Jones predicted in the 25 Jan 1968 LAT that he would complete 4,000 drawings before sending them to animators, to work on their own versions. The 9 Feb 1968 DV reported that layouts and designs were finished, and work on an estimated 7,200 feet of animated film was scheduled to begin in mid-Mar 1968. By 2 Oct 1969, post-production had begun, as noted in that day’s DV.

The Phantom Tollbooth opened on 24 Oct 1970 in sixty Los Angeles, CA, theaters, according to the 23 Oct 1970 LAT review. It was scheduled to be screened at Saturday and Sunday matinees for two weekends, before moving on to other cities, where it would also play for two weekends only, the 29 Nov 1970 LAT reported. The LAT review described the “limited exposure” release pattern as “strange and sad,” and praised the picture as a welcome offering in the current market, said to be devoid of children’s pictures. The review also described Jones’s animation style as “distinctly post-Disney in its acknowledgment of the likes of poster-style, hard-edge painting and pop art generally.”

Upon returning from school one day, Milo, a bored youth in San Francisco, California, finds a huge candy-striped package in his bedroom. Tearing off the wrappings, he uncovers a magic tollbooth, a red car, and a road map of the Kingdom of Wisdom. He drives through the tollbooth and discovers himself in a mystical cartoon world. There Milo encounters Officer Short Shrift, who gives him a traffic ticket with "I am" written on it, and the Whether Man, who is unable to make up his mind. He eventually winds up in the swampy Doldrums, where the yellow-eyed Lethargians try to convert him to their slothful way of life. Rescued from the Lethargians by a ticking "watch"-dog called Tock, Milo and the dog travel to the towns of Dictionopolis and Digitopolis. Tock explains that the two towns were at one time united under King Wisdom and his twin daughters, Sweet Rhyme and Pure Reason; but when Wisdom died, warfare broke out between King Azaz of Dictionopolis (who believes words are more important than numbers) and his brother, the Mathemagician of Digitopolis (who values numbers above words). Furthermore, the kings have banished Rhyme and Reason to the Castle-in-the-Air, which is guarded by the demons who inhabit the Mountains of Ignorance. Determined to restore peace to the land, Milo -- with the help of Tock, the Spelling Bee, and the foxlike Humbug -- subdues the forces of ignorance, returns Rhyme and Reason to the Kingdom of Wisdom, and joins in the celebration as the two kings finally realize that numbers and words are of equal importance. Although reluctant to leave his new friends, Milo drives back through the tollbooth into his bedroom. ...

Upon returning from school one day, Milo, a bored youth in San Francisco, California, finds a huge candy-striped package in his bedroom. Tearing off the wrappings, he uncovers a magic tollbooth, a red car, and a road map of the Kingdom of Wisdom. He drives through the tollbooth and discovers himself in a mystical cartoon world. There Milo encounters Officer Short Shrift, who gives him a traffic ticket with "I am" written on it, and the Whether Man, who is unable to make up his mind. He eventually winds up in the swampy Doldrums, where the yellow-eyed Lethargians try to convert him to their slothful way of life. Rescued from the Lethargians by a ticking "watch"-dog called Tock, Milo and the dog travel to the towns of Dictionopolis and Digitopolis. Tock explains that the two towns were at one time united under King Wisdom and his twin daughters, Sweet Rhyme and Pure Reason; but when Wisdom died, warfare broke out between King Azaz of Dictionopolis (who believes words are more important than numbers) and his brother, the Mathemagician of Digitopolis (who values numbers above words). Furthermore, the kings have banished Rhyme and Reason to the Castle-in-the-Air, which is guarded by the demons who inhabit the Mountains of Ignorance. Determined to restore peace to the land, Milo -- with the help of Tock, the Spelling Bee, and the foxlike Humbug -- subdues the forces of ignorance, returns Rhyme and Reason to the Kingdom of Wisdom, and joins in the celebration as the two kings finally realize that numbers and words are of equal importance. Although reluctant to leave his new friends, Milo drives back through the tollbooth into his bedroom. Transformed by his adventures into an alert and active boy, Milo runs outdoors to immerse himself in the real world.
